summary: Recent economic research shows that hospitals delivering more intensive treatment — especially early in the care process — can significantly reduce mortality for emergency patients. This challenges assumptions that higher spending is always wasteful and highlights the need to align payment models with value, not just cost reduction.

articles.title: Measuring Returns to Hospital Care: Evidence from Ambulance Referral Patterns
articles.summary: Using ambulance dispatch boundaries as an instrument, this study finds that hospitals with higher inpatient spending reduce 1-year mortality for emergency patients by 10%, suggesting early intensive treatment can be cost-effective.
articles.authors: Joseph J. Doyle Jr. et al.

implementation_examples.title: Hospital at Home models introduced to extend intensive care without discharging to SNFs
Medicare discussions on aligning reimbursement with longer-term outcomes

articles.title: Uncovering Waste in US Healthcare: Evidence from Ambulance Referral Patterns
articles.summary: This companion study to Doyle Jr. et al, 2015 uses the same ambulance-based randomization strategy and finds that high inpatient spending improves survival, while high outpatient spending (particularly SNF use) worsens it — highlighting post-acute SNF care as a key source of waste.
articles.authors: Joseph Doyle, John Graves, Jonathan Gruber

implementation_examples.title: Use of SNF outcomes and referrals being reconsidered in hospital performance metrics

articles.title: A Surgical Safety Checklist to Reduce Morbidity and Mortality in a Global Population
articles.summary: This multinational RCT evaluated the WHO surgical safety checklist across eight hospitals and found it reduced in-hospital mortality from 1.5% to 0.8% and complications from 11.0% to 7.0% in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery.

implementation_examples.title: Surgical safety checklist drops deaths and complications by more than one-third

articles.title: Prospective, multi-site study of patient outcomes after implementation of the TREWS machine learning-based early warning system for sepsis
articles.summary: A prospective cohort study of over 6,800 sepsis patients found that provider confirmation of the TREWS ML-based sepsis alert within 3 hours reduced in-hospital mortality by 18.7% and improved other outcomes like organ failure and length of stay.

implementation_examples.title: Bayesian Health's AI Helps Hospitals Reduce Sepsis Deaths By 18%

articles.title: New York State's Cardiac Surgery Reporting System: Four Years Later
articles.summary: An evaluation of New York’s Cardiac Surgery Reporting System showed that public reporting of risk-adjusted mortality led to large improvements in surgical outcomes between 1989 and 1992, particularly among hospitals and surgeons with initially high mortality rates.
articles.authors: E.L. Hannan, D. Kumar, M. Racz, A.L. Siu, M.R. Chassin

articles.title: Discharge after Hip Fracture Surgery by Mobilisation Timing: Secondary Analysis of the UK National Hip Fracture Database
articles.summary: A study of over 135,000 patients found that early mobilisation (within 36 hours of hip surgery) doubled the adjusted odds of being discharged within 30 days, suggesting a strong association between timely mobilisation and improved recovery and mortality outcomes.

implementation_examples.title: Improved Outcomes Associated With an Early Mobilization Protocol Among Hip and Knee Replacement Patients
